												I just gave this game a try since it pretends to be an "open-world driving game", and that got me curious. Alas, after just over one hour of trying to come to grips with it, I have to admit I give up on it. It's not an awfully bad game, far from it. The graphics are more than decent, considering it's a game from 2009. On the highest settings (not that there are that many settings...), the cars look nice and the environment is more or less ok - bar the awful pop-ups in front of you of several objects. The driving model is fair, nothing special, but when played with a controller it feels fine. The music, as so often with this type of game, is all too repetitive for my taste so I switched it almost immediately off. There are some possibilities for adding your own music tracks to the game, so for those interested in this, the game offers something extra.The bad thing about the game is the "gameplay" - actually, there hardly is any, at least I did not find much of it. There are several modes: a free patrol mode, in which I searched in vain for anything to-do other than driving through a generic-looking city with roadsigns that kept saying "Köln 2300m" all the time. You can do a normal city race, which is fine for just a quick try, but the "story mode" is what lets the game down. The various objectives are simply hilariously difficult - most of the time one has to damage an opponent to 100%, but whenever he gets further away than 200m, the mission has to be restarted. Since the AI miraculously can teleport itself down bridges or through walls, this got me first staring in disbelief and then lauging out loud. I guess this game can be fun to some, but to me it's a no-go: there are simply too many other good games out there, including large-scale racing games, to put any more time into this.Overall score: 3.5/10

												This game materialized in my library one day. I never purchased it, it was just there. I installed it out of boredom and expected the game to be no better than those "X SIMULATOR" games you see here on Steam. I was pleasantly mistaken, because this game, despite being made on an almost non-existent budget, is surprisingly solid. What the game lacks in originality, presentation, and innovation, it makes up for with solid controls, and really great vehicle physics. There's a fair amount of attention to detail here, too. Your car, and every other car in the game as well, can be absolutely smashed into an ugly mess, with way more convincing looking damage than what GTA IV and V have to offer. You can park in front of a train, let it smash your car's front grille in, go flying, land, and not be able to control your car at all because your front wheels are now several feet away racing eachother down the autobahn without you. The gameplay is pretty generic and repetitive, but still solid. You'll get bored eventually, but until then you'll have fun chasing criminals, smashing into everything, and racing. Traffic will move the ♥♥♥♥ out of your way when you turn on your sirens, and when you finally catch up to the bad guys and P.I.T. them into a wall, you'll have to hold them still there for a few seconds in order to "arrest" them. There's things to collect and vehicles to unlock, including an excavator and a massive armored personnel carrier with six wheels, which absolutely smashes everything out of its way including buses and large trucks, even in oncoming traffic. All of the cars are unlicensed rip-offs of real world vehicles, which I'm glad the developers managed to do. It's not a BMW, it's a Semir! They're different! We swear!All in all, it's a solid game. It's not the best game in the world, but it's definitely not bad either. It's just decent. A 5/10, or I guess 7.5/10 if you go by IGN's rating system. If you like racing and police chase games, and don't mind games with low budgets, pick this one up on sale.The developers of this game, sadly, stopped making video games in 2014. They were very well known in Germany, but virtually nobody knows about them outside of Germany. They specialized in racing games and their games were some of the best selling games to come out of Germany. Rest in peace Synetic, and if you guys are reading this, I loved World Racing 2 on the Xbox.

												Crash Time 2 is a series of games based on the German police drama "Alarm for Cobra 11: Autobahn Police". There was actually several games made under the Cobra 11 brand, then came Cobra 11 Nitro. However, none of these was exported. Next version, Cobra 11: Crash Time was exported  as "Crash Time", and that lead to the Crash Time II, and so on. (We're now up to Crash Time V). At its heart, Crash Time is an open-world mission-based driving sim with a fictional city for you to drive around in using variety of vehicles. CT2 has a good selection of German vehicles, none with actual names and logos, but they are readily recognizable, plus a few favorite foreign cars. The graphics are actually quite good, giving the amount of detail available for the cities and buildings. Some multilevel garages can be driven to the roof and back down via the spiral ramps. the Autobahns are nice and wide with plenty of places to speed, and many cars have nitrous injection added for that extra burst of power. The mission, on the other hand, are your typical police chase (either stop the car or crash him into toally disabled), checkpoint race (reach X checkpints, stop for 1 second in each), getaway (don't let the bad guys catch you), time trial (reach the destination via specified route before time runs out). CT2, however, added "jumping puzzles", where you must take the ramp at certain speeds to ensure you jump correctly onto certain locations in order to do something you can't do otherwise. And sometimes you need to chain the driving and jumping together, and that is just ridiculous. For example, one of the missions was "stop that barge from dumping waste into the canal" How do you do it? By taking ramps and JUMPING onto the barge (without falling into the canal, of course). That requires jumping across the canel, landing on the other side, make a left, jump ANOTHER ramp, then stop right on top of the barge (without falling off). All in... 45 seconds. ARGH! The city is large enough and open enough that "free roam" is quite possible Indeed, you are encouraged to "patrol" the city for missions to advance the campaign. Though in reality you just need to respawn at the regular start spots and few times, and/or scroll around the city map (fully zoomable in 3D!) for a "red arrow" which means mission starting point. Handling of the cars are simplified, and are exciting without being overly difficult. The campaign missions, however, have the dubious honor of having some of the WORST English dubbing done EVER in a game. The two voice actors are either very bored or acting too hard. Though this seem to reflect the type of TV show this was based on: more of action comedy than pure action. If you can find this game cheap, it is worth a try at least. It's not NFS: Hot Pursuit, but it has its own charms.

Driving the RC cars (bomb detonators) is particularly fun.The world is HUGE, and it's a lot of fun to explore. Granted, there aren't really "side missions", but it's fun to just drive around nonetheless. There were quite a few moments where I went off drops at max speed, and it gave me a real sense of adrenaline flying through the air (fortunately no one was around to mock me shouting, "Woah!!")The story is interesting enough to keep you engaged, but it won't win any awards. The same is true for the voice acting. For a racing game, it's probably slightly above par.A good selection of cars are available, and you can pick and choose the cars you use for some missions (though certain missions can only be performed with certain cars). They have completely different feels to them, but for the most part, you're going to want to stick with the faster vehicles for most missions.I paid $0.99 for the game, and I would honestly have been happy paying $5 for it. I definitely recommend it.The downsides to this game are the bugs, and here those are (with recommended workarounds if available):- On "wreck the car" missions, if you flip the opponent's car over, the car disappears and respawns somewhere near you (the same thing that your car would do if it got stuck upside down). If the opponent's car happens to respawn behind you, that means it will likely turn around and drive the other way. I recommend doing your best to not flip over the cars or completely pin them where they can't move. Just keep hitting them with force or get them behind you then keep bumping them as they try to pass you.- Sometimes, it's just plain hard to find a mission. You drive around for a while and nothing appears. In these cases, try switching cars (look for ones with mission indicators), and try switching starting locations. You shouldn't ever need to be driving around for more than a minute for the mission brief to play, so keep moving about until a mission appears. Annoying, but workable.- The navigation arrow is absolutely useless sometimes. It will recommend jumps over bridges when your car isn't fast enough to make the jump. Fortunately, the mini-map has a much better direction indicator that adjusts for different routes and recommends shortcuts. I highly recommend using that primarily (even though you have to look off the screen a bit).

I don't know if that's a sign that this port is badly optimized or that my computer is sh*ttier than I had previously thought. For reference, I can play project cars on medium settings with the same resolution and almost never go below 60fps. Not really an issue other than I'm a bit spoilt.*You still have to grind through the bland story missions to gain access to the good cars*In my case, it didn't really provide the entertainment I thought it was going to deliver. 												The first thing that you must keep in mind if you have purchased this game ( or got for free ) is that you didn't spend a whole lot of money for it. For this, you will be Thankful ; you do get what you pay for. Don't expect a Burnout Series game level of development and gameplay. If you want a ' quality ' game, be prepared to pay the premium and scroll past Crash Time 2.The game is based on a German TV show called ' Alarm für Cobra 11 – Die Autobahnpolizei Ausfahrt ', a TV show that I cannot figure out as to whether or not is a serious crime drama or a German spoof take on the 80's series, Miami Vice. If you are from an English speaking country, the TV show that it is based on looks really really bad ( I did some youtube research by watching a couple of episodes to try and better understand what this game is based on )Graphics :  I haven't seen a PC game since that late 90's that has such a short draw distance and pop in. You can actually see the grass grow as you drive by embankments. The developers must have heard ' Bloom ' and ' HDR  ' and thought ' you mean ' Glare ' as that is what you get. Glare then translates to making the screen bright white in some areas. The plus to this level of techincal wizardry is that you don't need an i7 and a pair of Titans to play this game. The specs required to play this game are from around 2003 i.e. if you are reading this review, your computer can run the game. Yes there are some slow downs, but in general, it's not a bad frame rate for a 2003 standard driving game. Unlicensed cars which are very obviously actual BMW, Mercedes, VW's, etc. The cars are not bad at all, hence why you can actually tell what they are based on ( or not badged as ). The city is well, German ( industrial, efficient and logically laid out but a little bland  ; mostly built in the last 70 years onwards due a disagreement with a couple of countries a number of years ago ).  Graphics wise, not the worst - not the best - kinda ' Eh ' if you can forgive the HDR ( or lack of ) and pop in that is.Gameplay : Hmmm. You have a car and can drive around - really enough said. The ' handling ' is an arcade racer, not a sim. Don't expect fantastic drifts, just understeer and poor brakes. I tend to use the handbrake instead of the normal brakes for stopping. The nearest driving experience would be if CrazyTaxi had a love child with an early TOCA game. The story is as deep as a standard cup of water but hey, you either paid $0.99 or got this game for free right?Voice acting : Voice acting needs a special mention all of it's own. You need to play the game to understand where I am coming from around this. I have NEVER heard such bad voice acting from ANY game, TV show, telemarketing scammer, etc. When I first heard the characters, it was quite amusing. As the game went on, it becomes, well a little bit creepy. Ever heard a 6 year old in a school play? Well it's a bit like that but spoken by a 40 plus year old guy.  Why really bad English accents? Why not German's speaking English? I think this would have worked better ( and they could have slipped in the word Squirrel for bonus points ) .... You have been warned. Controls :  I have read some reviews on this game that say that the controls are difficult. I did not experience this problem as I plugged in my generic USB gamepad AKA PS2 copy and configured to suit a PS2 layout. You MUST use the D Pad to control the menu up and down then use the top button to select ( Triangle for PS2 ) and circle equivalent ( PS2 ) to go back. If you use the keyboard at any point on the menu, the game pad will be disabled. It's really not very hard to figure out though. To configure, enter the control lay out menu and set the control for the button of your choice ( press enter on the keyboard, then the button on the game pad that you want to use for that control ). For those that have configured a DOS / Windows 95/98 game pad, it's back to those days. Once configured, controls were responsive and worked as you want them to.Conclusion :  Reading the above you are probably wondering why I am recommending this game? The fact remains that it is a very cheap ( or Free )  FULL game with graphics that exceed homebrew games. Buy it, but don't expect Burnout Paradise for $0.99c or Free. If you want Burnout Paradise, then don't be so cheap and buy it ( or wait for a Steam Sale 75% off ).Note that support for the game was ditched after about a year from release, but likely not for the reason that Apple use to ditch support to sell you another product ( though we are upto Crash time 5 according to the interweb )

												Bought this game on sale: 2,49€The missions are not only difficult but somewhat lack fun and precise gameplay.Sometimes you dont actually know what to do in certain missions or find out too late and see the game over screen far too soon. I had like 2 seconds already in the first mission and if you fail a target you have to start the process all over again.The graphics are ok keeping in mind that the game is made in 2009. There are some bugs in game like when cars cross the andreas cross they jump or easily have an accident which should have been fixed with a patch long ago and shows lack of support from developers. German voices are horrible and a joke, dialogs neither useful nor funny except some of the sarcastic advertisment which is seen on buildings or truck cargo containers. The music depends on your taste and can be switched off. Cars have some features like the horn, turn on alarm, blink etc. This game is not intended to be a driving simulator and therefor the physics of the vehicles are acceptable. I however cannot recommend the game for an average price of like 10 € since main gameplay is awfull. Either try Crash Time 3 or buy another open world game like sleeping dogs, watch dogs or GTA 4 or 5 or Driver San Francisco which are a bit more expensive but add much more fun in gameplay, better graphics, better voiceacting, bigger worlds and better music. The game seems to be a mix of Bournout and Need for Speed but you rather get those titles for like 10 bugs.The game also has no steam achievements to offer. 2,49€ is not a waste of money if you wanna try it out. 												Where can i start with this game?Well first off i got it for free so atleast im not annoyed that I payed the steep price of £6.99.Secondly, Imagine everything you know and love about driving games like stuntman (which IMO this is a poor copy of), now forget it all. The game handles very poorly, from not being able to ue the analog stick in menus to the the car being sluggish to turn one second, to spinning 360 the next.Continuing with controles, they are so random its not even amusing, (Y) is horn, (X) is siren (on, on silent, off), the right analog stick only has left and right in use and thats only for the respective indicators (im not even joking) and as far as i can tell, the bumpers do nothing at all (atleast in the tutorial anyway).Interface wise the game is also quite poor, your speedo, map, mission objective and distance to target are all in seperate parts of the screen so you find yourself looking around at everything but the road. The speedo also has this odd feature of telling you what speed you need to hit ramps at, it will do this by taking up 1/4 of your screen and having a huge green mark and arrow at the speed you need to be, this speed is NOT optional, too slow you fall into a gap/dont make the jump, too fast and the game will send you flying into anything that it feels could be in your way.There is also a replay cam that will replay what you did not 2 seconds ago (that seems about the extent og its record time) whenever it feels you've done something special, this is considered anything from a high speed overtake to a 45 degree turn, a 1080 aileron roll over a building or a 360 backflip over a roundabout? nah thats not replay worth (oh and your leads can get away while the replay is heppening).Gameplay. The random spawn for cars is so borked that I swear i saw a family car with a caravon on it pull out of an industrial complex, and this wasnt a one off mistake, about 30 cars where queing to get out of a police testing area. The waypoints are another thing that are non-optional, miss one by a smidge and you will find yourself doing a 180 or slamming it into reverse while your lead gets away. Lastly that brings me to the persuit mechanics, it told me to attempt to stop the van with some light taps, instead I got infron of it and forced it to stop. Not good enough. Ok its traiing i can forgive that, so 5 taps it is, then I have to dissable the vehicle, so I flip it on its side with some fancy driving, nope, didnt fill the damage indicator so it de and respawns to carry on.Overall this game was very poor, it looked ok back in 2010 when it was made im sure, but now its dated, jaded and needs to fade into the background.~Round Up~Story - unrated, I refused to play after the tutorial.Graphics - 7 - There not the worst and I'm sure when it was released they did look good.sound - 5 - forgetable OST with less than average voice acting topped with a siren that is all you can hear when its on. The only reason I didn't rate lower is becasue the crash sounds arn't that bad.Gameplay - 3 - Poor controles with a bad HUD and strange mechanics.Overall - 4 - It might have a good story and if your into games like stuntman you could get on with it but it just seems like a copy done wrong, if you like stuntman, break out the PS2 and play it, you'll have alot more fun, trust me. £6.99? I'd  still be anoyed if I'd paid £2.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #34 - Crash Time IISo the Oxford dictionary added janky to their list of words this year.janky (adj.): of extremely poor or unreliable quality.And it just so happens that janky sums up Crash Time 2 very nicely.I start, like with many games, by trying out the Tutorial.  So I'm start with a mission where I have to pursuit and stop a car.  Okay, sound simple enough.  In fact, I very quickly pin the car against a fence, and render it completely immobile.  Oh wait, apparently the game didn't expect me to do that so soon, so instead of giving me credit for stopping the car, it disappears and then respawns.  Now I have to chase it down again.Eventually I chase it down and this time I look long enough that the game rewarded me for it.  In the next part of the tutorial,  I have to chase the car again, except this time I have to ram it to do enough damage to stop it.  So I start ramming the car, and eventually I make the car flip over.  Awesome, I win, right?  Oh wait, no, instead of getting credit for stopping the car, the game just makes the car respawn.  Apparently it wants me to keep ramming the car.  Apparently this game equates thinking outside the box with cheating.So after ramming my way to victory, next I'm on a mission where it tells me to hit the "Action Button" to launch a remote control drone.  It doesn't tell me which button on the controller that is, it just says "Action Button" like it's obvious.  I proceeded to mash every single button my controller and none of them worked.  Oh wait, I forgot to push down on my thumbsticks.  There we go, the action button was apparently mapped to pushing down on the right thumbstick.  Totally my first choice for an "action button", and not those pesky X or A buttons.  So now that I've figured out how to hit the action button, it spawns what looks like a stick of dynamite on wheels.  Now I'm controlling a remote control drone.  I then drive it to my target and hit the "Action Button" again and blow it up.  Now I'm back in my car and it wants me to launch another drone.  Okay, so now as I am driving this other drone I have to hit this jump just right, and it will launch me over a fence to my target.  Well I wasn't going fast enough so I end up vertical against the fence.  Now I can't get myself off the fence.  I hit a bunch of different buttons, trying to get back into my car instead of the drone.  I hit the back button and sure enough I'm back in my car.  Except I didn't go back to my car, the game teleported the car to me.  So now I'm in my car stuck vertically on the fence.  I do eventually get through tutorial and decide to try and actual game.  So I pick the option to Patrol and get a mission where I have to go to the harbor to escort a car that's being delivered.  So I start by driving towards the harbor as directed.  But then as I get part way towards the harbor, suddenly my screen is black, well most of my screen anyway.  The UI is there, including my speedometer and minimap, but there's no longer a road.  Apparently I'm supposed to drive to the harbor blindfolded.


Driving to the harbor blindfolded 
A Screenshot of Crash Time II
By: EvilSpaniard




I restart the mission and this time it lets me make it to the harbor without blindfolding me.  So now I'm escorting this truck.  The truck has the prototype car in it, and in turn 2 cop cars are escorting the truck.  So I have to follow the truck from behind, but not too close, and not too far either.  I guess I'm like the undercover backup that no one is supposed to know about.  So I follow the truck for a little ways and 2 vans drive up and start taking out the cop cars.  I better help those poor cops, so I floor it to catch up.  Oh wait, that would be common sense.  I forget this game doesn't reward me for common sense because I'm breaking the rules, because now I'm too close to the truck.  Nevermind the mortal danger here, I'm outpacing the games scripting, and we can't have that.I can just picture this conversation where the publisher warns the developers of this game, "Hey guys, the game is coming along, but it could really use some polish".  Except the developers misunderstood and made all of the cars in the game shiny.   Unfortunately, no amount of shine could possibly cover over this janky turd of a game.

												Not worth your time. Doesn't live up to the name. It is not about crashing or damaging cars, it's about conducting boring routine tasks as a german police officer. First and foremost, the car models are quite well done, with excellent graphics for the time it came out. Apparently that is where the studio spent all their time and money. The game honestly feels like a graphical showpiece for car modeling. Besides the cars, the environments look blocky and bad. The gameplay also suffers. The worst offender is the car driving, as I can't remember driving mechanics so poor. Your small boring generic sedan, which is basically the only car you drive during the game, handles like a boat. Turns are taken terribly, and breaking seems to take forever to slow down. There is no handbreak or way to take quick turns, which means turning basically means slowing down to a complete stop then slowly turning. Backing up doesn't work either. Once you've stopped you press break and it changes you to reverse, then you need to let off the button and press it again to start backing up. There is no way to look at controls in game. I had no idea what anything did. I tried looking for a handbrake, and there seemed to be 2 different ones, but once didn't turn you faster, it only flung your forward at an angle for some reason when you were slowing down. There is no way to look behind you, which you actually need to do in the game, so I have no idea why they wouldn't include it. You have to use this tiny unhelpful rearview mirror. Then there is the gameplay. The single player makes no sense and isn't untuitive. There is a case, single race, and patrol at multiple different locations - tabs. Apparently you just select a patrol with a flag and then drive around and wait to get a call, which makes no sense for a single player. The voice acting may be the worst and cheesiest I've ever heard. Missions have multiple parts, but if you fail 2/3 in you have to start from the beginning for no reason. This is easy because if you get spun around or accidentally hit the wrong turn, as is common with the terrible direction indicator on your small map, or you get stuck behind the tiny railing that you can't get through (logic?) and you are following someone, you will fall behind the certain distance. Then there are the parts you have to break a car to win. You are a cop but you have no gadgets or guns to help you, all you can do is crash into cars........sounds like the plan of no cop ever. Destroying vehicles takes forever because damage modeling makes no sense, and you only do tiny damage at a time. I flipped a car over 3 times within 30 seconds and he would just drive off with no damage to the top or side of his car. It never makes sense how the cars get damaged. So you have to destroy a car but it literally takes 7 minutes of you following it around hitting it, having no idea how far you are in destroying it, because it never changes in performance. Then there are missions that have you drive to certain spots to check things out, but instead of 3-4 spots, the game has you go to FOURTEEN spots, which should take about 12-15 min, for no reason but to inflate length and give you busy work. That isn't fun because the random german city is boring and generic looking, with nothing interesting to look at. There is really nothing to make this game worth playing. Good vehicle graphics though, even if they are super un-interesting to use or look at. 4/10.

												55/100TL;DR. Fun car racing game. Good environment, lots of destructable items, relatively large open-world map. Poor voice acting but story is ok. Many missions seem impossibley hard. Totally not worth 10$. Try to buy it on sale (I got it for $2 I think). Good for at least a few hours of free roaming destruction and some missions.Pros:+ Driving mechanics - while not entirely realistic, they are more than adequate and feel appropiate for this game style.+ Collisions - very satisifying to just plow through some poor soul who did not pull over fast enough.+ Soundtrack - I liked it at least, the rock/metal soundtrack. felt appropiate for the fast-paced chase style racing.+ Open World - Very large with a pretty good environment. On high, the graphics are not terrible (its actually pretty close to the steam screenshots above).+ Destructable Items - pretty much solely streetside items, there is more than enough stuff to run into and cause mayhem. Always a plus.Cons:- Voice Acting - Beyond miserable. Its sooooooo cliche and often in proper grammer that no common person (let alone cop) would talk like. I know they are on a budget, but still. Come on.- Cutscenes - Not too bad, but they get annoying when you have to watch them like 8 times over (you cant skip through them).-  Motion Blur - Really annoying and I can't seem to turn it off. Sort of makes it lag too....and the biggest one of them all- MISSIONS - Even on easy, some of them seem impossibly hard. Many require you to chase some sort of perp and stop his car. Fair enough, but "stopping" them is defined as inflicting 100% damage on their car. Merely getting them to spin out and pinning them or flipping them isnt enough - the enemy will just respawn a few dozen meters behind you and go the opposite way. Compounding this is that there is often a limit to how far they can be from you before you fail the mission. It is super easy to spin out or miss a turn and be done. The AI takes impossibly tight turns very fast and utilizes unexpected shortcuts that you dont see until you miss them. One could easily spend 10-15 min chasing down a guy until he is at 100% damage, but we can't. There's also a timer too.Overall chance of mission success on easy? Hahahaha.Normal/Hard? Don't want to even think about it.**** EDIT: ****It should be said that not all of the missions are like this. There are some that are actually quite fun and require skill to do right - but just enough to make it a little dificult but doable. These are the ones that really make the game and the reason my score isn't worse than it is.

												55/100TL;DR. Fun car racing game. Good environment, lots of destructable items, relatively large open-world map. Poor voice acting but story is ok. Many missions seem impossibley hard. Totally not worth 10$. Try to buy it on sale (I got it for $2 I think). Good for at least a few hours of free roaming destruction and some missions.Pros:+ Driving mechanics - while not entirely realistic, they are more than adequate and feel appropiate for this game style.+ Collisions - very satisifying to just plow through some poor soul who did not pull over fast enough.+ Soundtrack - I liked it at least, the rock/metal soundtrack. felt appropiate for the fast-paced chase style racing.+ Open World - Very large with a pretty good environment. On high, the graphics are not terrible (its actually pretty close to the steam screenshots above).+ Destructable Items - pretty much solely streetside items, there is more than enough stuff to run into and cause mayhem. Always a plus.Cons:- Voice Acting - Beyond miserable. Its sooooooo cliche and often in proper grammer that no common person (let alone cop) would talk like. I know they are on a budget, but still. Come on.- Cutscenes - Not too bad, but they get annoying when you have to watch them like 8 times over (you cant skip through them).-  Motion Blur - Really annoying and I can't seem to turn it off. Sort of makes it lag too....and the biggest one of them all- MISSIONS - Even on easy, some of them seem impossibly hard. Many require you to chase some sort of perp and stop his car. Fair enough, but "stopping" them is defined as inflicting 100% damage on their car. Merely getting them to spin out and pinning them or flipping them isnt enough - the enemy will just respawn a few dozen meters behind you and go the opposite way. Compounding this is that there is often a limit to how far they can be from you before you fail the mission. It is super easy to spin out or miss a turn and be done. The AI takes impossibly tight turns very fast and utilizes unexpected shortcuts that you dont see until you miss them. One could easily spend 10-15 min chasing down a guy until he is at 100% damage, but we can't. There's also a timer too.Overall chance of mission success on easy? Hahahaha.Normal/Hard? Don't want to even think about it.**** EDIT: ****It should be said that not all of the missions are like this. There are some that are actually quite fun and require skill to do right - but just enough to make it a little dificult but doable. These are the ones that really make the game and the reason my score isn't worse than it is.

												I found Crash Time II to be a rather enjoyable car chase/racing game that allows you to speed through a European city and wreck havoc, while no one seems to mind.  The trick to really enjoying this game, however, is that you have to get past the frustrating first mission.  You know how most games give you easy tasks at the beginning of the game, and just about the time you think you got the hang of it, the difficulty ramps up until you begin to feel like a failure?  Crash Time II does just the opposite.   The first mission requires you to perform a rather tricky maneuver, followed by extensive car chase in which you need to disable the car you are pursuing by ramming it over and over until it's an immobile pile of metal.  This is more difficult than it sounds, especially when you are new to the game.  In fact, it took me over three hours to complete the level.  After that, however, the game became much easier, with the next several missions being timed tasks, races, or chases that only require pinning your target instead of destroying them.  Yes, the game has several other frustrating missions that require multiple attempts, but by this time your skill is better and they don’t take as long or seem as daunting. I played this game both with a controller and with a keyboard and mouse.  Personally, I have no preference and found both methods adequate.Helpful Tips to make the game more fun and reduce frustration: 1.  Play in easy mode.  The chase missions are hard enough -- a simple wrong turn can allow an enemy to escape in an instant.  2.  Read the manual.  At least scan it. I spent a lot of time driving around doing nothing early in the game until I read the manual and figured out why missions weren't triggering.  3.  When you are required to completely disable another vehicle, avoid pinning it for too long.  Back off and let it get going before ramming it again.  What the game neglects to tell you is that all the criminals have graduated from Hogwarts and, when pinned, will suddenly disappear and reappear elsewhere, sometimes far enough away that they can escape before you even have time to turn your vehicle around.  Finally, the voice acting is brilliant!  No, I didn’t say it was good, well written or well acted.  Just brilliant.

												I don't normally review games unless I wanna give my two cents but this game? I have to, it's mixed review rate just isn't right. That being said, let's actually review this game and the whole one hour I put into it.I know one hour doesn't seem like much but to me it was enough to review most of this game.This game is like a weird mix of Burnout and GTA without being able to get out of your vehicles, it's a lot like Starsky and Hutch for the PS2 minus the guns, that game was a blast with a steering wheel and light gun. c:I bought this game for $0.99 and just recently saw it was a giveaway by Bundle Stars so I put it on my family account as well so my family could play it and it also reminded me that I should give it a try and I did.The actual review: Pros:+Semi-realistic vehicle handling and physics.+Ability to use warning indicators and turn signals as well as your siren and lights and silent police lights(No siren.).+Decent damage system.+You can pretty much destroy everything on a city wide rampage in the semi with a trailer.+Cheesy voice acting.+Great looking for being 6-7 years old.+Tons of video options and resolutions.+Great input support, works with all my gamepads and of course an X360 pad and I believe it has steering wheel support.+Stable, never crashed on me once and it runs great.+Splitscreen racing.+Manual and Automatic settings, gear shifting and more.+Fun to slam AI around during missions that warrant it.Cons:-Sometimes terrible AI and the AI spawn system is completely borked, AI will spawn miles away from you sometimes in a mission where you have to be within a few metres of them and thus causes you to fail and must restart the mission from the beginning, there are no checkpoints but most missions are pretty short. So try not to flip AI vehicles as a sort of fix.-Cheesy voice acting, not completely a negative, it's sometimes pretty hilarious listening to the voice actors putting on fake accents and faking feeling and integrity in their lines.-Not much depth to the game or story, but this game isn't really about story as it is gameplay.-Some AI is incredibly difficult to take down and may take up to twenty minutes to take down a single car smaller and slower than your vehicle which is kind of realistic but also kind of annoying if you just want to be done with the mission.-No online multiplayer and no splitscreen/online free roam/co-op.Overall, my final verdict would be 7/10, the game has bad voice acting and poopy AI at times but the game is still rather fun especially to go on a rampage and destroy anything and everything. This game has been so far extremely solid for me, no FPS drops, no crashing and everything is maxed on my system while maintaining at least 60FPS at all times.My suggestion: Wait until this game is like $3 or cheaper to purchase. It's mostly just one of those fun games to go back to and basically drive around destroying everything, taking out bad guys or leisurely strolling around and going with the flow of traffic and following road signs, etc.

												Crash Time 2 is an odd mix, but very enjoyable as a driving simulator for cruising around in the depicted german town. I'll preface by saying that I haven't played more than a few missions, but have spent hours cruising around.You get the brief impression from loading the game that it may have been re-branded from a more conventional german road driving simulator, but it almost liberates the player from taking their time on the road too seriously. The voice actors continue this first impression, causing the gamer to question exactly what subliminal german propaganda is being pumped through their speakers - because clearly, it can't be that superficial.. Yet, for all of its faults, there are plenty of great qualities. 1. The graphics are still nice and shiny on newer directX releases, and it holds up well over the span of 5 years - a virtual eternity, so to speak.2. The almost apathetic mixture of citizens and police driving around makes for some catastrophic crashes while business as usual goes on around them. 3. The driving itself, while not exactly precise in terms of the on-the-road handling physics, is pretty fun. It maintains a good balance between lively handling and classic arcade driving. The chases are a little easy if we're honest, but the crashes make it worthwhile.4. The comedy gold. If you start to look at the voice acting less as an actual attempt to create a dramatic environment and more of a strange video game cameo of mystery science theater 3000 post-translation, you'll be able to appreciate the rich social commentary presented between the lines. Bonus points for trying to drive with no front wheels, just a stream of sparks originating from your low-speed collision.5. The damage contest. While it's not a great idea when you're racing, one of the best parts of the game is seeing just how much property damage you can rack up before "The engine exploded."..4. Being $2.49 on sale occasionally. Very, very hard to complain about that.In short, if you come into the game expecting more than flat-out level driving performance, you'll probably be a little underwhelmed. But, if you load it up just to drive around and have a little fun driving like a maniac without the GTA-style shooting, it's a great way to mindlessly pass a few hours!

												I found Crash Time II to be a rather enjoyable car chase/racing game that allows you to speed through a European city and wreck havoc, while no one seems to mind.  The trick to really enjoying this game, however, is that you have to get past the frustrating first mission.  You know how most games give you easy tasks at the beginning of the game, and just about the time you think you got the hang of it, the difficulty ramps up until you begin to feel like a failure?  Crash Time II does just the opposite.   The first mission requires you to perform a rather tricky maneuver, followed by extensive car chase in which you need to disable the car you are pursuing by ramming it over and over until it's an immobile pile of metal.  This is more difficult than it sounds, especially when you are new to the game.  In fact, it took me over three hours to complete the level.  After that, however, the game became much easier, with the next several missions being timed tasks, races, or chases that only require pinning your target instead of destroying them.  Yes, the game has several other frustrating missions that require multiple attempts, but by this time your skill is better and they don’t take as long or seem as daunting. I played this game both with a controller and with a keyboard and mouse.  Personally, I have no preference and found both methods adequate.Helpful Tips to make the game more fun and reduce frustration: 1.  Play in easy mode.  The chase missions are hard enough -- a simple wrong turn can allow an enemy to escape in an instant.  2.  Read the manual.  At least scan it. I spent a lot of time driving around doing nothing early in the game until I read the manual and figured out why missions weren't triggering.  3.  When you are required to completely disable another vehicle, avoid pinning it for too long.  Back off and let it get going before ramming it again.  What the game neglects to tell you is that all the criminals have graduated from Hogwarts and, when pinned, will suddenly disappear and reappear elsewhere, sometimes far enough away that they can escape before you even have time to turn your vehicle around.  Finally, the voice acting is brilliant!  No, I didn’t say it was good, well written or well acted.  Just brilliant.
